fields.description:
As per EC2 API reference the query parameter to be used for suppressing a block device mapping is BlockDeviceMapping.n.NoDevice. 

euca2ools does not populate this query parameter in the upstream request.

EC2 reference API: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/ApiReference-query-RunInstances.html

{noformat}
[root@eucahost-51-167 ~]# euca-register -n bfebsimage --root-device snap-69C63FD6 -b /dev/sda1=snap-69C63FD6 -b /dev/sdb=none --debug
2013-01-24 14:41:02,817 euca2ools [DEBUG]:Method: POST
2013-01-24 14:41:02,817 euca2ools [DEBUG]:Path: /services/Eucalyptus/
2013-01-24 14:41:02,818 euca2ools [DEBUG]:Data: 
2013-01-24 14:41:02,818 euca2ools [DEBUG]:Headers: {}
2013-01-24 14:41:02,818 euca2ools [DEBUG]:Host: 192.168.51.167:8773

192.168.51.167:8773

{noformat}


Furthermore, suppressing a device mapping in registration request is invalid. But this may have to be handled by the server side and not the client tools
fields.summary: euca-register/euca-run-instance: query parameter to suppress block device mapping is not populated

comments.body:
That's news to me.  If suppressing a mapping in a register request is invalid then I'm surprised that {{RegisterImage}} requests allow that to begin with.  Where did you learn that?

|| Name || Description || Required ||
| _{{BlockDeviceMapping.N.NoDevice}}_ | Suppresses a device mapping.\\ Type: Boolean\\ Default: true | No |

Block device mapping semantics are same across ec2. Since no mappings exist prior to the image registration, it does not make sense to suppress a mapping during the registration. So it looks like ec2-register returns an error. Here is what I saw:

\\
{noformat}
[root@swathi-centos ~]# ec2-register -n swathibfebs3 --root-device-name /dev/sda1 --block-device-mapping /dev/sda1=none --debug
Using AWS acces key: AKIAJTJKXWFPMRXK4PPA
Client.InvalidBlockDeviceMapping: remove is not a valid logical type
Status Code: 400, AWS Service: AmazonEC2, AWS Request ID: 1d879d7e-15f4-40d3-8491-872c30b53a0c, AWS Error Code: InvalidBlockDeviceMapping, AWS Error Message: remove is not a valid logical type
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.handleErrorResponse(AmazonHttpClient.java:610)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.executeHelper(AmazonHttpClient.java:310)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.execute(AmazonHttpClient.java:164)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.invoke(AmazonEC2Client.java:6069)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.registerImage(AmazonEC2Client.java:4626)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.Jec2SdkImpl.registerImage(Jec2SdkImpl.java:201)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.cmd.RegisterImage.invokeOnline(RegisterImage.java:153)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.cmd.BaseCmd.invoke(BaseCmd.java:1037)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.cmd.RegisterImage.main(RegisterImage.java:196)

[root@swathi-centos ~]# ec2-register -n swathibfebs3 --root-device-name /dev/sda1 --block-device-mapping /dev/sda1=snap-3e650f7f:16 --block-device-mapping /dev/sdb=none --debug
Using AWS acces key: AKIAJTJKXWFPMRXK4PPA
Client.InvalidBlockDeviceMapping: remove is not a valid logical type
Status Code: 400, AWS Service: AmazonEC2, AWS Request ID: 22ed896d-a9c8-43ed-b956-38b628a2b93a, AWS Error Code: InvalidBlockDeviceMapping, AWS Error Message: remove is not a valid logical type
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.handleErrorResponse(AmazonHttpClient.java:610)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.executeHelper(AmazonHttpClient.java:310)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.execute(AmazonHttpClient.java:164)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.invoke(AmazonEC2Client.java:6069)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.registerImage(AmazonEC2Client.java:4626)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.Jec2SdkImpl.registerImage(Jec2SdkImpl.java:201)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.cmd.RegisterImage.invokeOnline(RegisterImage.java:153)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.cmd.BaseCmd.invoke(BaseCmd.java:1037)
	at com.amazon.aes.webservices.client.cmd.RegisterImage.main(RegisterImage.java:196)
{noformat}

But there _are_ mappings that exist before registration.  They're specified in the image manifest.  It would be interesting to see if EC2 responds the same way to requests that try to suppress mappings that appear there.
The same goes for instance storage that instances get by default, namely instance-store instances' ephemeral storage.
Oh, I did not know that device mappings can exist prior to image registration. Will try suppressing such a mapping and see what happens.

Swathi will investigate further.

There is a client side fix and a potential server side.
[~gholms] Fixed the server side logic. Please parse the command line parameters for 'none' and populate NoDevice parameter.

commit 091e7e5f078704e3a676da4dcc049b5f9763aeff
Author: Garrett Holmstrom <gholms@fedoraproject.org>
Date:   Thu Feb 7 14:57:52 2013 -0800

    Serialize NoDevice block device mappings correctly
    
    Fixes TOOLS-180
This should be fixed in alpha 1, which should send {{NoDevice=none}} for this now.

[~gholms] As per AWS API NoDevice is a boolean parameter with true/false values

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/ApiReference-query-RegisterImage.html

Can you please add the parameter 'BlockDeviceMapping.n.NoDevice=true' in the request to the server only when you encounter the option '-b <block device>=none' in the euca-register or euca-run-instances commands?

As per the AWS in the comment above, euca2ools should parse the {{'-b <block device>=none'}} and populate the request parameter {{'BlockDeviceMapping.n.NoDevice=true'}} before sending it to the server.
I uploaded a new build that sends {{true}} instead of {{none}}.  Does that do what you're looking for?
Yep, that does it. Thank you [~gholms]
Verified that euca2ools 3.0 populates {{BlockDeviceMapping.n.NoDevice=true}} mapping in the upstream request when it encounters {{<devicename>=none}} block device mapping
